**Introduction**

In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful.

Praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds. We praise Him, seek His help, seek His guidance, turn to Him in repentance, and ask His forgiveness. We seek refuge in Allah from the evils of our souls and the bad consequences of our deeds. Whomever Allah guides is the guided one, and whomever He leaves astray, you will not find for him a protecting guide. We send prayers and peace upon the Beloved Chosen One and the Selected Messenger, the Master of Creation and the Beloved of the Truth, Muhammad bin Abdullah, the trustworthy Arab Prophet, may my Lord's prayers and peace be upon him, his family, his companions, and those who follow his path until the Day of Judgment.

Now then:

The Holy Quran is the eternal miracle with which Allah Almighty supported His Messenger, peace be upon him. It is the general address directed to all minds and understandings, the protection and cure for all ailments and diseases, and the purification and innocence from the darkness of doubt and illusions. The Almighty distinguished it by revealing it piecemeal according to events and the gradual legislation of rulings, and He, the Mighty and Majestic, collected it in a collection of utmost precision and regularity, until its arrangement became one of its sciences which ancient and modern exegetes cared for with great attention. Through it, we stand upon one of the aspects of the inimitability of the Quran, in addition to understanding meanings, knowing purposes, preferring between opinions, and removing ambiguity. From this standpoint, ancient and modern exegetes cared for it, with varying degrees of interest and depth in this subject. However, Imam Al-Shawkani had another stance, as he called for turning away from it and claimed that there is no benefit in it, and criticized those interested in it. He mentioned that in the introduction to his Tafsir, but he did not remain firm on his stance, as he mentioned some aspects of correlations (Munasabat) between verses in the folds of his Tafsir. In this research, we present his words, then respond to them with general responses, followed by detailed responses to the most important issues he raised in the course of his talk about Munasabat. And Allah is the Grantor of success and the Guide to the straight path.

**Preface**

**First: With the Tafsir and the Mufassir (Exegete)**

One of the masterpieces of Tafsir books and its comprehensive foundations is the Tafsir of Imam Al-Shawkani named "Fath al-Qadir al-Jami' bayna Fannay al-Riwayah wa al-Dirayah min 'Ilm al-Tafsir" (The Opening of the All-Powerful, Combining the Two Arts of Narration and Knowledge from the Science of Exegesis). This Tafsir is considered a basic reference in its field; this is because it included Tafsir by narration (Riwayah), which relies on the four sources of traditional Tafsir:
1. Interpretation of the Quran by the Quran.
2. Interpretation of the Quran by the Sunnah.
3. Interpretation of the Quran by the sayings of the Companions.
4. Interpretation of the Quran by the sayings of the Successors (Tabi'in).

This Tafsir also included Tafsir by opinion (Ra'y), which is the interpretation of the Holy Quran through Ijtihad (independent reasoning) after the exegete's knowledge of the Arabic language, standing upon the causes of revelation, and knowledge of the abrogating and abrogated, the general and specific, and other Quranic sciences, alongside his reference to traditional Tafsir which is considered the primary reference for the exegete.

Imam Al-Shawkani needs no introduction: He is a prominent figure in jurisprudence and a leader of da'wah and reform in his era, and an encyclopedic writer. His lineage goes back to the village of Shawkan, one of the villages of Sana'a. He was born in the year 1173 AH and grew up in the city of Sana'a, memorizing the Quran in its Great Mosque. He grew up in a house of knowledge and virtue, for his father Ali bin Muhammad bin Ali Al-Shawkani held the position of judge of Sana'a. He drank from his knowledge and benefited from his library teeming with mother books in various sciences and arts. Al-Shawkani moved between the scholars of Sana'a just as a bee moves from flower to flower and from orchard to orchard, sipping nectar to bring forth from its belly a drink of varying colors containing healing for people. He read with his sheikhs the mother books in various sciences: in creed, jurisprudence and its principles, language and its literature, Hadith and its sciences, logic, the etiquette of research and debate, and in Tafsir and its sciences, and other sciences in which he excelled. He wrote biographies for his sheikhs in his book "Al-Badr al-Tali' bi Mahasin man ba'd al-Qarn al-Sabi'" (The Rising Full Moon regarding the Virtues of Those after the Seventh Century).

He, may Allah have mercy on him, has numerous works, most of which are printed. Among the most important are his Tafsir "Fath al-Qadir", his book "Nayl al-Awtar Sharh Muntaqa al-Akhbar", "Al-Fawa'id al-Majmu'ah fi al-Ahadith al-Mawdu'ah", "Al-Badr al-Tali' bi Mahasin man ba'd al-Qarn al-Sabi'", "Al-Sayl al-Jarrar al-Mutadaffiq 'ala Hada'iq al-Azhar", "Irshad al-Fuhul ila Tahqiq al-Haqq min 'Ilm al-Usul", "Tuhfat al-Dhakirin fi Sharh 'Uddat al-Hisn al-Hasin", and others. (1)

**Second: Definition of the Science of Munasabat (Correlations):**

Munasabat is the plural of Munasaba. Munasaba in language means resemblance, similarity, and closeness (2). From it comes Al-Nasib: the close relative, like brothers, a cousin, and the like, between whom there is a 'Munasaba', i.e., a tie linking them, which is kinship.
Among the Usulis (scholars of principles of jurisprudence): Munasaba in the cause ('Illah) in the chapter of Analogy (Qiyas) is the description close to the ruling, because if its closeness to it occurs, the existence of the ruling is thought upon the existence of that description (3).
Among the rhetoricians: Proportionality (Tanasub) is the arrangement of brotherly meanings that harmonizes and does not conflict (4).
In the terminology of exegetes: Ibn al-Arabi defined it in his book "Siraj al-Muridin" as: "The connection of the verses of the Quran with one another so that they are like a single word, consistent in meanings, regular in structures." (5)
Al-Zarkashi defined it in "Al-Burhan" as: A reasonable matter which, if presented to minds, is accepted by them. (6)
Thus, the science of Munasaba is a science concerned with highlighting the aspects of connection and proportionality of verses and Surahs.

**Presentation and General Responses**

Al-Shawkani claims that researching this science is a form of affectation (takalluf), that there is no benefit from it, and that it is speaking by pure opinion which is forbidden. He criticizes Al-Biqa'i and others for their attention to this science. Below is a presentation of his words with general responses to them:

Al-Shawkani says in the introduction of his Tafsir, opposing the science of Munasaba, denying it, and criticizing those interested in it:
"Know that many exegetes came with an affected science and waded into a sea they were not tasked to swim in, and consumed their times in an art that does not return a benefit to them. Rather, they threw themselves into speaking by pure opinion which is forbidden in matters related to the Book of Allah Almighty. That is because they wanted to mention the correlation between the Quranic verses listed in this arrangement present in the Mushafs, so they came with affectations and arbitrariness from which fairness is innocent and the speech of eloquent people is exalted, let alone the speech of the Lord Almighty. Until they singled that out with authorship and made it the most important purpose of composition, as Al-Biqa'i did in his Tafsir and those who preceded him, as mentioned in his sermon." (1)

We agree with Al-Shawkani that affectation is forbidden in Tafsir or otherwise, and that it is not permissible to speak by pure forbidden opinion. However, the science of Munasabat requires reflection and contemplation, not affectation and arbitrariness. It is a science indispensable for any exegete because it aids in understanding the meaning, preferring between opinions, knowing the general objectives of verses and Surahs, and other benefits. The correlation might be clear and evident, or it might need precise contemplation and deep reflection. If the correlation is hidden, it should not be denied or negated. As it has been said:
*And if you do not see the crescent moon, then submit to people who saw it with eyes.*

Al-Shawkani questions: How can we seek correlations for verses when they were revealed piecemeal according to events, so there is no correlation between them then?

book_title: Al-Shawkani's Stance in his Tafsir regarding Munasabat
text:
Regarding this, Al-Shawkani says:
"Indeed, this is among the strangest things heard by one who knows that this Quran continued to be revealed piecemeal according to the incidents necessitating its revelation since the revelation of inspiration to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him and his family, until Allah Almighty took him unto Himself. Every sane person, let alone a scholar, does not doubt that these incidents necessitating the revelation of the Quran are different in themselves, nay, they may be contradictory, such as prohibiting a matter that was lawful and making lawful a matter that was prohibited, and establishing a matter for a person or persons that contradicts what was established for them before. Sometimes the speech is with the Muslims, sometimes with the disbelievers; sometimes with those who passed, sometimes with those present; at times regarding worship, at times regarding transaction; a time in encouragement, a time in intimidation; an occasion in glad tidings, an occasion in warning; a phase in a worldly matter, a phase in a Hereafter matter; once in future obligations, and once in past stories. If the causes of revelation differ this much and diverge this divergence with which harmony is not facilitated, then the Quran revealed in them is, considering itself, different like their difference. So how can a sane person seek correlation between the lizard and the whale, water and fire, the sailor and the camel driver?"

book_title: Al-Shawkani's Stance in his Tafsir regarding Munasabat
text:
Similar to this is what Imam Al-Izz bin Abd al-Salam said, as quoted by Al-Zarkashi in Al-Burhan:
Imam Al-Izz bin Abd al-Salam, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "Munasaba is a good science, but it is a condition for the goodness of connection of speech that it occurs in a unified matter connected from its beginning to its end. If it occurs due to different causes, the connection of one to the other is not conditional. He said: Whoever connects that is affecting what he cannot do except with a weak tie from which good speech is protected, let alone the best of it. For the Quran was revealed over twenty-odd years regarding different rulings and for different reasons. Whatever is like that, it is not possible to link some of it to others, since it is not proper to link the actions of the Deity in His creation and rulings to one another given the difference in causes and reasons, like the actions of kings, rulers, and muftis, and the actions of a human himself in compatible, different, and opposing matters. No one has the right to seek linking some of those actions to others given their difference in themselves and difference in their times. End quote." (1)

However, Al-Izz, may Allah have mercy on him, does not deny the existence of Munasaba absolutely, but considers it good if it occurs between unified speech connected from beginning to end.

I say: The Holy Quran was revealed piecemeal according to incidents and events and observing gradualism in legislation, but it was collected in breasts (memory) and lines (writing) according to how it is in the Preserved Tablet, where Gabriel, peace be upon him, used to teach the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, the place of every verse in its Surah, in addition to the arrangement of Surahs as will be explained. If its revelation piecemeal has wisdoms and benefits that are not hidden, then its collection in this divinely appointed arrangement has wisdoms and benefits. And if its revelation piecemeal is a characteristic by which it was unique among previous books, then this arrangement is a characteristic of its characteristics. Is it reasonable that its arrangement in the Mushaf is different from the order of its revelation and then there is no wisdom for that? Why do we strive in seeking wisdoms and objectives of divine legislations and then demand ignoring the wisdom of the divine arrangement of the Noble Mushaf!

book_title: Al-Shawkani's Stance in his Tafsir regarding Munasabat
text:
Imam Al-Zarkashi said in Al-Burhan: "Some of our verifying sheikhs said: He who said that correlation is not sought for the noble verses because they are according to scattered occurrences has erred. The decisive speech is that they are according to occurrences in revelation, and according to wisdom in arrangement. The Mushaf is like the noble scriptures in accordance with what is in the Hidden Book, all its Surahs and verses arranged by divine instruction (Tawqif). If a memorizer of the Great Quran were asked for fatwa regarding multiple rulings, or debated about them, or dictated them, he would mention the verse of every ruling according to what he was asked. If he returned to recitation, he would not recite as he gave fatwa nor as it was revealed piecemeal, but as it was sent down wholly to the House of Glory (Bayt al-Izza). Among the clear miracles are its style and dazzling order, for it is (a Book whose verses are perfected and then presented in detail from [one who is] Wise and Acquainted) (1). He said: What should be researched in every verse first of all is its being complementary to what is before it or independent. Then regarding the independent one, what is the face of its correlation to what is before it? In that is abundant knowledge. Likewise in Surahs, the face of their connection to what is before them and what they were driven for is sought." (2)

I say also: Not all Quranic Surahs were revealed piecemeal. Indeed, among the long Surahs are those revealed wholly, like Surah Al-An'am for example, and Surah Al-Fatiha and others. So do we not seek a correlation for them as well? (3) Also, some Surahs had large sections revealed wholly, so do we leave talking about their interconnection and correlation?

text:
I also say: Isn't it strange that Al-Shawkani criticizes Al-Biqa'i for his interest in this science in his Tafsir "Nazm al-Durar"? Then we see him praising this Tafsir and the path of its author in it, saying in his book "Al-Badr al-Tali'" during his biography of him: "Whoever examines deeply his book translated for him in Tafsir which he made about the correlations between verses and Surahs knows that he is among the vessels of knowledge, excessive in intelligence, combining the science of reason and tradition. Often something in the Book confuses me, so I return to the extensive and concise Tafsirs and find nothing that cures, and I return to this book - Nazm al-Durar - and find in it what is beneficial mostly." (1)

Al-Shawkani claims that researching this science is nothing but "opening doors of doubt and expanding the circle of suspicion for one in whose heart is a disease or whose disease is mere ignorance and deficiency. For if he finds scholars talking about proportionality between all verses of the Quran and singling that out with authorship, it becomes established in his mind that this is a necessary matter and that the Quran is not eloquent nor miraculous unless the face requiring the correlation appears and the matter necessitating the connection becomes clear. So if he finds difference between verses and returns to what the speakers said about that and finds it pure affectation and clear arbitrariness, what he was safe and sound from sparks in his heart." (2)

I say: The correlation of verses and Surahs is an aspect of Quranic rhetoric, where there is quality of casting, splendor of order, beauty of structures, and ingenuity of styles. This correlation is a face of the faces of inimitability (I'jaz), and no one said that inimitability is based on it alone, or that Quranic rhetoric is represented only in it. The aspects of inimitability are multiple, and the rhetoric of the Quran is branched and its styles and colors are numerous.

Al-Shawkani also says, denying the possibility of linking between verses and Surahs and finding the thematic unity of the Quran: "You know that if a man of knowledge undertook the task of finding correlation between what a man of eloquence said in his sermons, letters, and compositions, or to what a poet of the poets said in poems that are sometimes praise and other times satire, sometimes love poetry and sometimes elegy, and other different types; and this undertaker intended that collection and correlated between its paragraphs and sections, then affected another affectation and correlated between the sermon he gave on Jihad, the sermon he gave on Hajj, and the sermon he gave on marriage and the like, and correlated between the composition in condolence and the composition in congratulation and what resembles that; this undertaker for such [a task] would be considered mentally afflicted, playing with his times, tampering with his life which is his capital. If such is the case regarding this status, which is riding folly in human speech, how do you see it being in the speech of Allah Almighty, whose rhetoric incapacitated the eloquent of the Arabs and whose fluency silenced the eloquent of Adnan? Every deficient and perfect person knows that Allah Almighty described this Quran as Arabic and revealed it in the language of the Arabs and followed in it their paths in speech and ran with it in discourse. We have known that their orator used to stand in a single situation and bring different arts and divergent ways, let alone two situations, let alone situations, let alone all that he said as long as he lived. Likewise their poet. Let us suffice with this alert to this corruption in whose arenas many verifiers stumbled. We only mentioned this discussion in this place because the speech here has shifted to the Children of Israel after it was before it with the father of mankind, Adam, peace be upon him. If an affecter says: 'How did this correlate to what was before it?' We say: 'No how. So leave aside a spoil whose sides were shouted in, and bring a hadith; what is the hadith of the riding camels?'" (1)

I say: Is it reasonable to measure human speech against the speech of the Creator of humans? Is this matter acceptable? Are revelation sent down from Allah and a stray rhyme in the worlds equal?

book_title: Al-Shawkani's Stance in his Tafsir regarding Munasabat
text:
Do we compare human speech, which is not free from defect and deficiency, with the speech of the Subtle, the Acquainted, the Knower of what is in the breasts? Do we equate this with that? While Allah Almighty says about His Noble Book: {A Book whose verses are perfected and then presented in detail from [one who is] Wise and Acquainted {1}} [Surah Hud]. It is a book perfected in its order, perfected in its purposes, perfected in its construction, perfected in its consistency. It is a book where parts of it resemble others in the splendor of styles, precision of words, sublimity of purposes, unity of construction, correlation of verses, and interconnection of Surahs. Allah Almighty says in a Surah: {Allah has sent down the best statement: a consistent Book wherein is reiteration. The skins shiver therefrom of those who fear their Lord; then their skins and their hearts relax at the remembrance of Allah. That is the guidance of Allah by which He guides whom He wills. And one whom Allah leaves astray - for him there is no guide {23}}

This is a general response to the words of Imam Al-Shawkani, may Allah have mercy on him. The hiddenness of aspects of correlation is not a proof for denying it. It has been said: *And if you do not see the crescent moon, then submit to people who saw it with eyes.* It is strange that despite his stance preventing correlation as is clear from his words, we see him in his Tafsir citing numerous correlations. We will have a pause with them, God willing, through the subsequent topic where we offer detailed responses to some raised issues.

**The Second Topic**
**Detailed Responses**

**First Requirement: His Claim that Munasabat is a Science without Benefit**

Imam Al-Shawkani claims that the science of Munasabat is a science without benefit. The truth is that this science has numerous benefits and useful fruits about which we will speak in this topic, God willing. We say, and success is from Allah:
From the benefits of studying this science:

**Knowing an Aspect of the Aspects of the Inimitability of the Holy Quran:**
The Holy Quran: Allah's profound argument, His renewed signs, and the Messenger's eternal miracle. A miracle for every generation and tribe, a miracle in every era and land, a miracle for all humanity in various stages of its life, nay, a miracle also for the Jinn.

book_title: Al-Shawkani's Stance in his Tafsir regarding Munasabat
text:
Allah Almighty said: {Say, "If mankind and the jinn gathered in order to produce the like of this Qur'an, they could not produce the like of it, even if they were to each other assistants." {88} And We have certainly diversified for the people in this Qur'an from every [kind of] example, but most of the people refused [anything] except disbelief. {89}}
Among the most prominent aspects of the inimitability of the Holy Quran is its inimitability in terms of the correlation of its verses and the harmony and embrace of its Surahs. The Holy Quran is a single thematic unity, and its verses and Surahs are a single structure:
*Like pearls increasing in beauty when strung... And not decreasing in value when unstrung.*
Al-Suyuti mentioned in his book "Mu'tarak al-Aqran fi I'jaz al-Quran" among the aspects of inimitability: [The fourth aspect of aspects of inimitability: the correlation of its verses and Surahs and the connection of some to others so that they are like a single word, consistent in meanings, regular in structures]. However, he repeated in this place what he had previously mentioned in Al-Itqan. (1)
Imam Al-Razi said in his Tafsir of Surah Al-Baqarah: "Whoever contemplates the subtleties of the order of this Surah and the wonders of its arrangement knows that the Quran, just as it is miraculous in terms of the eloquence of its words and the honor of its meanings, is also so in terms of its arrangement and the order of its verses. Perhaps those who said it is miraculous in terms of its style meant that. However, I saw the majority of exegetes turning away from these subtleties, not attentive to these secrets. The matter in this chapter is nothing but as was said:
*And the star, eyes belittle its image... And the fault is with the eye, not with the star in smallness.*" (2)
Al-Baqillani says in his book "I'jaz al-Quran": "The third aspect of its inimitability aspects: It is of innovative order, wondrous composition, reaching an extremity in rhetoric to the limit that creation is known to be incapable of."

He also says: "...We have contemplated the order of the Quran and found all that it deals with of the faces (1) we mentioned before to be on one level in goodness of order and wonder of composition and arrangement. There is no disparity in it, nor descent from the highest rank, nor stooping in it to the lowest rank. Likewise, we contemplated the modes of address in long and short verses and saw inimitability in all of them on one level differing not. Also, people's speech may vary when retelling a single story a clear variation and differ a great difference. We looked at the Quran in what is retold of a single story and found it not different nor varying." (2)
He also says: "As for the method of the Quran, its order, composition, and arrangement, minds wander in its direction, are bewildered in its sea, and stray short of its description. We mention to you in detailing this what you can use as evidence for the purpose, seize the span, reach the destination, conceive its inimitability as you conceive the sun, be certain of the extremity of its rhetoric as you are certain of the dawn, bring close the obscure to you, and ease the difficult for you. Know that this is a science of noble place, great standing, few students, and weak companions." (3)

text:
Then Al-Baqillani mentions numerous examples indicating the splendor of the Quranic order, among which we mention the following:
"Contemplate the Surah in which the Ant is mentioned (Al-Naml) and look into it word by word and section by section. He began by mentioning the Surah until He clarified that the Quran is from Him, so He Almighty said: {And indeed, you are receiving the Qur'an from One, Wise and Knowing}. Then He connected to that the story of Moses, peace be upon him, and that he saw a fire {He said to his family, "Stay here; indeed, I have perceived a fire. I will bring you from it information or bring you a burning torch that you may warm yourselves."}. And He said in Surah Ta-Ha in this story {that I may bring you from it a torch or find at the fire guidance}. And in a place {that I may bring you from it information or a burning coal from the fire that you may warm yourselves}. He has varied the modes and brought the mention of the story in varieties to teach them their inability regarding all ways of that. For this reason, He said {Then let them produce a statement like it} to be more effective in incapacitating them and more apparent as an argument against them. Every word of these words, even if informing about a story, is eloquent in itself, complete in its meaning. Then He said {But when he came to it, he was called, "Blessed is whoever is at the fire and whoever is around it. And exalted is Allah, Lord of the worlds"}. Look at what He ran the speech for, regarding the highness of this call's matter and the greatness of this praise's status. How it was organized with the first speech, how it connected to that introduction, and how He connected with it what followed of informing about Lordship and what He indicated it with of turning the staff into a snake and making it a proof guiding to Him and a miracle leading to Him. Look at the single words standing by themselves in beauty and in what they contain of noble meanings. Allah Almighty said in Surah Al-Hijr: {Indeed, it is We who sent down the Qur'an and indeed, We will be its guardian. {9}} And He, Glory be to Him, said addressing His Noble Messenger: {Move not your tongue with it, [O Muhammad], to hasten with recitation of it. {16} Indeed, upon Us is its collection [in your heart] and [to make possible] its recitation. {17} So when We have recited it [through Gabriel], then follow its recitation. {18} Then upon Us is its clarification. {19}} Surah Al-Qiyama. So the Quran, even if revealed piecemeal, Allah Almighty guaranteed to collect it in the heart of His Messenger, peace be upon him, arranged, as the Trustworthy of Revelation Gabriel, peace be upon him, used to explain to the Messenger, peace be upon him, the position of every verse and the place of every Surah...

book_title: Al-Shawkani's Stance in his Tafsir regarding Munasabat
text:
When the Quran was collected in one Mushaf during the reign of Uthman, may Allah be pleased with him, its arrangement which the Companions learned from the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, was observed in its collection.
As for what Al-Hakim and others narrated from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both: I said to Uthman bin Affan, may Allah be pleased with him: What compelled you to take Al-Anfal, which is from the Mathani (oft-repeated/medium length), and Al-Bara'ah (Al-Tawbah), which is from the Mi'in (hundreds), and join them together and not write the line 'In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful' between them, and place them in the Seven Long ones? What compelled you to do that? Uthman, may Allah be pleased with him, said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah be pleased with him (sic), used to have times when Surahs with numbers (of verses) were revealed to him. When something was revealed to him, he would call some of those who wrote it and say: 'Place this in the Surah in which such and such is mentioned.' And a verse would be revealed to him and he would say: 'Place this in the Surah in which such and such is mentioned.' Al-Anfal was among the first revealed in Medina, and Bara'ah was from the last of the Quran. Its story was similar to its story. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, passed away and did not clarify to us that it was part of it. Therefore, I joined between them and did not write the line 'In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful' between them. (1)

text:
Even assuming the authenticity of the hadith, Abdullah bin Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, did not object to their arrangement in the Mushaf. Rather, he was asking about the wisdom of joining them together, making them like a single Surah, and considering them among the Seven Long ones, knowing that Al-Anfal is from the Mathani and Bara'ah is from the Mi'in.
Uthman, may Allah be pleased with him, responded by stating that the arrangement of the Mushaf follows the Divinely Appointed Arrangement (Tawqifi) which the Companions learned from the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him; there is no room for Ijtihad (personal reasoning) in that. Uthman joined them and considered them as one Surah only because of the similarity between them in subject and goal, even though Al-Anfal was among the first revealed in Medina and Al-Tawbah among the last. But the criterion is not the order of revelation. Hence, he did not separate them with the Basmala and considered them as a single unit or single Surah with which the section of the Long ones ends.
Supporting this is what Al-Nahhas narrated in Al-Nasikh wa al-Mansukh from Uthman, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: "Al-Anfal and Bara'ah were called 'The Two Pairs' (Al-Qarinatan) in the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him; that is why I put them in the Seven Long ones." (1) Meaning he counted them as one Surah with which the Seven Long ones end.
There is nothing in the hadith indicating that Uthman, may Allah be pleased with him, is the one who arranged them in the Mushaf or that he merged them making them one Surah. If Al-Anfal and Al-Tawbah were one Surah, they would have had one name, and the number of Quranic Surahs would be 113. But the Ummah is agreed that the number of Surahs is 114, and that each has an independent name. The reason Surah Bara'ah did not begin with the Basmala is because of the disavowal and threat to the polytheists mentioned at its beginning; so it did not start with the Basmala which implies mercy, because the context does not suit talking about mercy.
Al-Tibi said: "This speech indicates that they descended in the status of one Surah and the Seven Long ones were completed by it. Then it was said the Seven Long ones are Al-Baqarah, Bara'ah, and what is between them." (2)

I have previously spoken about the stage of Quran collection during the reign of Uthman, may Allah be pleased with him, and the documentation and precision that characterized this collection. Uthman, may Allah be pleased with him, formed a committee of senior reciters, entrusted them with the task of collection, and supervised them. Uthman, may Allah be pleased with him, did what he did with the consultation of the Companions. He was not one to be arbitrary in opinion or use Ijtihad against a text, and no objector objected to that.
Al-Bukhari narrated in his Sahih with his chain from Ibn al-Zubayr who said: I said to Uthman bin Affan, may Allah be pleased with him, regarding (And those who are taken in death among you and leave wives...) Al-Baqarah 234: The other verse abrogated it, so why do you write it or leave it? Meaning why do you write it, or he said why do you leave it written even though it is abrogated? He said: O nephew, I do not change anything from its place. (1)

**Partitioning the Quran According to its Arrangement:**
The Messenger, peace be upon him, had a daily portion (Wird) of the Book of Allah Almighty which he was keen to read so that he would complete the Quran every now and then. The noble Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, had their daily portions, and some of them sought guidance from the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, in determining their portion.
* Imam Ibn Khuzaimah narrated in his Sahih with his chain from Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, felt some pain one night. When morning came, it was said: O Messenger of Allah, the trace of pain is apparent on you. He said: Indeed, despite what you see, praise be to Allah, I read the Seven Long ones last night." (2)

* And Ibn Majah narrated in his Sunan with his chain from the hadith of Aws bin Hudhayfah, and in it... So I said: O Messenger of Allah, you were late coming to us tonight. He said: It occurred to me [to complete] my portion (hizb) of the Quran, so I disliked coming out until I completed it. Aws said: So I asked the Companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him: How do you partition the Quran? They said: Three, five, seven, nine, eleven, thirteen, and the portion of the Mufassal. (1)
* And Al-Bukhari narrated in his Sahih with his chain from the hadith of Abdullah bin Amr, and in it: He, peace be upon him, said to him: How do you fast? I said: Every day. He said: And how do you complete [the Quran]? I said: Every night. He, peace be upon him, said: Fast three days in every month and read the Quran in every month. I said: I can do more than that. He said: Fast three days in the week (Friday). I said: I can do more than that. He said: Break fast for two days and fast one day. I said: I can do more than that. He said: Fast the best fast, the fast of David: fasting one day and breaking fast one day, and read [the Quran] once every seven nights. I wish I had accepted the concession of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, for I have grown old and weak. He used to read the seventh of the Quran to some of his family during the day; what he reads he presents during the day so it would be lighter for him at night. If he wanted to gain strength, he would break fast for days and count them, then fast days like them, hating to leave anything upon which he parted from the Prophet, peace be upon him." (2)

text:
Imam Ahmad narrated in his Musnad from Wathila bin al-Asqa' who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "I was given the Seven Long ones in place of the Torah, the Mi'in in place of the Psalms (Zabur), the Mathani in place of the Gospel (Injil), and I was favored with the Mufassal." (1)
These four divisions of the Holy Quran indicate its Divinely Appointed Arrangement.

From the foregoing, it becomes clear to us:
* The Holy Quran descended wholly from the Preserved Tablet to the House of Glory, and from the House of Glory to the heart of the Chosen One, peace be upon him, piecemeal.
* The arrangement of the Quran as it is in the Mushaf is Divinely Appointed (Tawqifi); there is no room for opinion in it, nor do the Companions have any intervention in its regard. It was by the command of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, as he learned it from the Trustworthy of Revelation Gabriel, peace be upon him. The arrangement of the Mushaf is according to what is recorded in the Preserved Tablet, an arrangement that involves numerous wisdoms encompassed only by the Revealer of this Book, Majestic is His Majesty.
* Gabriel, peace be upon him, used to study the Quran with the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, in the month of Ramadan every year, until the year the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, passed away, he reviewed it with him twice, observing its arrangement present in the Preserved Tablet and upon which is the Uthmani Mushaf.
* The Messenger, peace be upon him, had a daily portion of the Book of Allah Almighty which he was keen to read until he completed the Quran every now and then. The noble Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, had their daily portions. Some of them memorized the entire Quran during the life of the Messenger, peace be upon him, and some completed memorizing it after his death, peace be upon him, all according to its arrangement.

* Among the manifestations of Allah's preservation of His Book is that He preserved it arranged as it is in the Preserved Tablet, from which the Quran descended wholly to the lowest heaven before descending piecemeal according to occurrences, incidents, and occasions.

**The Third Requirement**
**His Claim That There is No Correlation Between the Discussion of the Children of Israel in Surah Al-Baqarah and What Preceded It**

*****
Imam Al-Shawkani, in his interpretation of the verse in Surah Al-Baqarah {O Children of Israel, remember My favor which I have bestowed upon you and fulfill My covenant upon you that I will fulfill your covenant from Me, and be afraid of [only] Me {40}} etc., went to the view that there is no correlation between the discussion of the Children of Israel and the story of Adam that preceded it, and that researching this is a form of affectation, for the discussion of the Children of Israel is new speech cut off from what is before it.
However, if we look closely and reflect for long, we would find numerous links and many correlations that do not require arbitrariness or affectation to highlight. We will have pauses with them in this topic, God willing. We say, and success is from Allah:

**Correlation between the Discussion of the Children of Israel and the Axis and Purposes of the Surah:**
One of the substantial pillars and basic axes of this noble Surah is: Talking about the Children of Israel, their past and present, revealing their secrets, warning against their plots and corruptions, reminding them of Allah's favors upon them, warning them lest they befall the like of what befell their ancestors, inviting them to believe in what Allah revealed to His Prophet and Chosen One, peace be upon him, opening the door of repentance and acceptance before them, and warning Muslims against following their ways. Therefore, the discussion about them took up numerous verses in multiple places of the noble Surah...

text:
Surah Al-Baqarah is a Madinan Surah. Its revelation began after the Hijra to support and build the nascent Muslim society in that new atmosphere which brought together believers and other factions, the most dangerous of which were the Jews and the Hypocrites. It was necessary to talk about them in detail and clarification suitable for their mention in the longest Surah of the Quran, that Surah whose revelation took nine years. The discussion about the Jews in particular was one of the basic axes around which the noble Surah revolved - for they are the most dangerous hostile forces to this religion, and they have diverse methods and numerous means in cunning, deception, and plotting which the Quran alerted us to so we would be wary of them.
In this regard, Professor Sayyid Qutb, may Allah have mercy on him, says:
"The wisdom of the prolonged discussion about the Jews: This campaign - whether what came of it in this lesson or what follows in the context of the Surah - was necessary first and foremost to demolish the claims of the Jews, expose their plot, and clarify their reality and the reality of their motives in plotting against Islam and Muslims. It was also necessary to open the eyes and hearts of Muslims to these intrigues and plots directed at their new society and at the foundations on which it stands; just as they are directed at the unity of the Muslim rank to destabilize it and spread sedition within it...

book_title: Al-Shawkani's Stance in his Tafsir regarding Munasabat
text: On the other hand, it was necessary to warn Muslims against the slippery paths where the feet of the nation succeeded before them stumbled, so it was deprived of the position of vicegerency and stripped of the honor of upholding Allah's trust on earth and His methodology for leading humanity. This campaign was interspersed with explicit and implicit directives to Muslims warning them of those slippages, as will come in the second part of it. How much the Muslim community in Medina needed this and that! And how much the Muslim nation at all times needs to contemplate these directives and to study this Quran with an open eye and insightful sense, to receive from it the instructions of the divine, supreme leadership in its battles it wages against its traditional enemies; and to know from it how to respond to the deep, malicious plot they direct at it tirelessly, by the most hidden means and most cunning ways..." (1)

text: Professor Qutb, may Allah have mercy on him, clarifies that the discussion about the Children of Israel is one of the basic subjects and substantial pillars of this noble Surah. He says, may Allah have mercy on him: "This Surah comprises several subjects. But the axis that gathers them all is a single double axis where the two main lines are strongly interconnected. On one hand, it revolves around the stance of the Children of Israel towards the Islamic Call in Medina, their reception of it, their confrontation with its Messenger, peace be upon him, and the emerging Muslim community based on it... and all matters related to this stance, including that strong relationship between the Jews and Hypocrites on one side, and between the Jews and Polytheists on the other. On the other hand, it revolves around the stance of the Muslim community at its inception; and preparing it to carry the trust of Da'wah and Vicegerency on earth, after the Surah announces the refusal of the Children of Israel to carry it, their breaking of Allah's covenant regarding it, and their stripping of the honor of true affiliation to Abraham - peace be upon him - the owner of the first Hanifiyya (true monotheism), and enlightening the Muslim community and warning it against the stumbles that caused the stripping of the Children of Israel of this great honor... All subjects of the Surah revolve around this double axis with its two main lines, as will come in its detailed review." "To clarify the extent of the connection between the axis of the Surah and its subjects on one hand, and the course of the Da'wah early in Medina and the life of the Muslim community and its circumstances on the other... it is good to shed light on the summary of these circumstances which the verses of the Surah were revealed to confront initially. With the constant reminder that these circumstances in general are the circumstances that the Islamic Call and its people continued to face - with slight difference - throughout ages and times; from its enemies and allies alike. This makes these Quranic directives the constitution of this eternal Call; breathes into these texts a life that renews to face every age and phase; and raises them as landmarks for the path before the...

**A Word on the Context:**

The Surah began by talking about Quranic guidance and people's stance towards it. Then came the first call in the Surah directed to all people inviting to the worship of Allah alone, for He, Glory be to Him, is the Creator, the Ordainer, the Manager, the Provider. Since the talk at the beginning of the Surah was about the Holy Quran as a book of guidance, talk about it came again from another perspective, which is its being a living, eternal, renewed miracle, with intimidation of those turning away from it, doubting it despite the appearance of proof and clarity of the path. The verses also carried glad tidings to the righteous believers of eternity in gardens of bliss. The context moved to talk about an eloquent style the Quran often takes to approximate meanings and establish them in minds in tangible molds; it is the style of striking parables, that lofty style which did not escape the criticism of the disbelievers.

text: Then was the reminder of the blessing of the first and second creation, and yet there are those who took the path of disbelief and persisted in it. Allah Almighty said: {And give good tidings to those who believe and do righteous deeds that they will have gardens beneath which rivers flow. Whenever they are provided with a provision of fruit from there, they will say, "This is what we were provided with before." And it is given to them in likeness. And those who have believed know that it is the truth from their Lord. But as for those who disbelieve, they say, "What did Allah intend by this as an example?" Then will you not reason? {44} And seek help through patience and prayer, and indeed, it is difficult except for the humbly submissive [to Allah] {45} Who are certain that they will meet their Lord and that they will return to Him. {46} O Children of Israel, remember My favor which I have bestowed upon you and that I preferred you over the worlds. {47} And fear a Day when no soul will suffice for another soul at all, nor will intercession be accepted from it, nor will compensation be taken from it, nor will they be aided. {48}} etc. verses...

book_title: Al-Shawkani's Stance in his Tafsir regarding Munasabat
text: Abu al-Saud said in his Tafsir: "'O Children of Israel' is a coloring of speech and directing it to a specific group of disbelievers contemporary to the Prophet to remind them of the varieties of favors poured upon them, after directing it to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and commanding him to remind them all of the general favor to the children of Adam entirely by His saying Almighty (And when your Lord said) etc. and (And when We said to the angels) etc. Because the meaning as indicated is: Convey My speech to them and mention to them when We made their father a vicegerent on earth and prostrated to by angels, peace be upon them, and honored him by teaching names and accepted his repentance." (1)

book_title: Al-Shawkani's Stance in his Tafsir regarding Munasabat
text: Al-Biqa'i, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "...Since the disbelievers were two types: a type whose disbelief was pure, and a type mixed with hypocrisy and deception. And the pure type was of two types: a type having no knowledge from a previous book, who are the polytheists of the Arabs, and a type having a book from which they know the truth. Allah Almighty mentioned the pure type encompassing both its knowledgeable and ignorant parts, saying Glory be to Him {Indeed, those who disbelieve - it is all the same for them whether you warn them or do not warn them - they will not believe {6} Allah has set a seal upon their hearts and upon their hearing, and over their vision is a veil. And for them is a great punishment {7}}. Then He followed it with the type of hypocrites so [believers] would be wary of their deception, saying Glory be to Him {And of the people are some who say, "We believe in Allah and the Last Day," but they are not believers {8}} etc. verses. When He finished that and what followed it of commanding Oneness, establishing its proofs, pouring forth its virtues, wondering at those who disbelieved despite the establishment of proofs, warning against those calamities, and soliciting sympathy by mentioning favors: He began mentioning a part of the pure [disbelievers] who are like the hypocrite in that they know the truth and hide it. The hypocrite became familiar with disbelief then quit it and showed clothing in Islam while continuing on disbelief internally. This part - meaning the Children of Israel - was upon belief in this Prophet before his mission. When he called them, they erased the faith they were clothed in and showed disbelief, and their state continued on showing disbelief and hiding the knowledge which is the principle of faith. Their condition, as you see, is most similar to the condition of hypocrites; that is why you see them paired with them in much of the Quran. He delayed them only due to the length of their story and what it contains of proofs of prophethood and signs of messengership by revealing what they hid of the details of their conditions..." (1)

book_title: Al-Shawkani's Stance in his Tafsir regarding Munasabat
text: Regarding the consistency of the discussion about the Children of Israel with the context, the author of "Al-Zilal", may Allah have mercy on him, says: "Then we notice from the aspect of artistic and psychological consistency in the Quranic performance, that the start of this round fuses with the conclusion of the story of Adam, and with the suggestions we pointed to there. This is an aspect of complementarity in the Quranic context between stories and the context in which they are presented: The context proceeded before that establishing that Allah created everything on earth for man. Then the story of Adam's vicegerency on earth by Allah's explicit precise covenant; his honoring over angels; the command and forgetfulness, regret and repentance, guidance and forgiveness; and equipping him with the first experience in the long struggle on earth, between forces of evil, corruption, and destruction represented by Iblis, and forces of good, righteousness, and construction represented by man holding fast to faith. The context proceeded with all this in the Surah. Then He followed it with this round with the Children of Israel, mentioning Allah's covenant with them and their breaking of it; His favor upon them and their denial of it; and arranging upon this their deprivation of vicegerency, prescribing humiliation upon them, and warning the believers of their plot as He warned them of their slippages. So there was an apparent connection between the story of Adam's vicegerency and the story of the Children of Israel's vicegerency, and a clear consistency in context and performance. This is all alongside the broad claim that they alone are guided; that Allah is pleased only with them, and that all religions are false and all nations astray except them! Which the Quran invalidates in this round, establishing that everyone who believes in Allah and the Last Day and does righteous deeds from all religions, they have their reward with their Lord and no fear will be concerning them, nor will they grieve..." (1)

book_title: Al-Shawkani's Stance in his Tafsir regarding Munasabat
text: He also says: "Reviewing the places where the story of the Children of Israel occurred here and there shows that it agrees with the context in which it was presented, complementing its goals and directives... It is here consistent with the context before it. The context of honoring man, the covenant to him, and forgetfulness. Including indications of the unity of humanity, unity of Allah's religion revealed to it, unity of His messages, with glances and touches on the human soul and its constituents, and the consequences of deviating from these constituents to which man's vicegerency on earth was attached; whoever disbelieves in them disbelieves in his humanity, loses the reasons for his vicegerency, and relapses into the animal world. The story of the Children of Israel is the most frequent story in the Holy Quran; care in presenting its situations and lesson is apparent, suggesting Allah's wisdom in treating the affair of this Muslim Ummah, raising it, and preparing it for the Great Vicegerency..." (1)

book_title: Al-Shawkani's Stance in his Tafsir regarding Munasabat
text:
Furthermore, Imam Abu Hayyan al-Andalusi has good words clarifying the consistency of the discussion about the Children of Israel with what preceded it, where he says, may Allah have mercy on him: "His saying Almighty (O Children of Israel, remember My favor) etc. verses: This is the opening of speech with the Jews and Christians. The appropriateness of speaking to them here is apparent. That is because this Surah opened by mentioning the disbelievers stamped with misery, mentioning the hypocrites and mentioning sentences of their conditions, then commanded people entirely to worship Allah Almighty, then mentioned the inimitability of the Quran to other things He mentioned. Then He alerted them by mentioning their origin Adam and what happened to him of eating from the tree after the prohibition from it and that the motive for him to do that was Iblis. These two groups, meaning the Jews and Christians, were People of the Book showing following of messengers and imitating what came from Allah Almighty. Their mention was included generally in His saying (O mankind, worship) etc. the verse. So He singled out their mention here specifically since speech with polytheists and hypocrites had passed, and speech with Jews and Christians remained. So He spoke to them here and mentioned what requires them to believe in this Book as they believed in their previous books. Speech with them suited the story of Adam peace be upon him because after they were given clear explanation and evident proof mentioned in the Torah and Gospel regarding fulfilling the covenant and believing in the Quran, a contrary (behavior) appeared from them by their disbelief in the Quran and the one who came with it." (1)

**Correlation between the Discussion of the Children of Israel and Surah Al-Fatiha:**
When He, Glory be to Him, informed in Surah Al-Fatiha about His exclusive entitlement to praise due to what He Almighty is described with of attributes of Majesty and qualities of Perfection - for He is the Praised One and continues to be for the favors He showed and generosity He extended - He clarified in Surah Al-Baqarah a side of His favors Almighty, which includes His favor upon the Children of Israel, His mercy upon them, reminding them of the Day of Judgment, and inviting them to worship Him and seek help from Him alone.

book_title: Al-Shawkani's Stance in his Tafsir regarding Munasabat
text:
Since the supplication of the believers was for guidance to the straight path, the path of those upon whom Allah has bestowed favor, not of those who have evoked [His] anger - who are the Jews - nor of those who are astray - who are the Christians, Surah Al-Baqarah dealt with the Jews in some detail, just as Surah Al-Imran spoke about the Christians, and talk about both groups appeared in Surahs Al-Nisa and Al-Ma'idah. This is of the chapter of detailing after summarizing. Thus the connection becomes clear to us between Surah Al-Fatiha which falls in the arrangement of the Mushaf before Surah Al-Baqarah.

**Correlation of the Discussion of the Children of Israel with the Title of the Surah:**
A clear correlation. The story of the Cow is one of the greatest evidences and clearest examples indicating the nature of the Children of Israel, where sterile argument, obstinacy, questioning divine commands, mocking prophets, and making things difficult for themselves, in addition to their concealment of truth and hardness of heart despite the succession of facts and arrival of softening signs. Also, the noble Surah revealed to us the secrets and hidden things of the Jews; it ripped open (baqarat) these facts which time had folded and Jews sought to hide with their propaganda methods based on clothing truth with falsehood and concealing truth. From here appears to us the connection between the title of the Surah and the talk about the ill intention, malicious inner self, and corruption of the Jews' natures as mentioned in this noble Surah (1).

**Correlation between the Introduction of the Surah and the Discussion of the Children of Israel:**
* Since the noble Surah opened by talking about the Quran as a book of guidance {Alif, Lam, Meem {1} This is the Book about which there is no doubt, a guidance for those conscious of Allah {2}}, talk came about an aspect of that guidance which is His informing about previous nations to take lessons and sermons from their conditions, inviting them to follow the path of guidance, warning the pious of their plots, enlightening them about their natures, and warning them against following their ways.

book_title: Al-Shawkani's Stance in his Tafsir regarding Munasabat
text:
* Also, when He Almighty mentioned in the beginning of the Surah the stance of the pious towards Quranic guidance and their attributes of faith, Allah Almighty invited the Children of Israel to join this group and walk on its path. He Glory be to Him invited them to remember His favors, fulfill His covenant, fear Him, believe in what was revealed to the Seal of His Messengers, peace be upon him, fear Him Almighty with true piety, establish prayer, and give zakah. He Almighty said {Alif, Lam, Meem {1} This is the Book about which there is no doubt, a guidance for those conscious of Allah {2} Who believe in the unseen, establish prayer, and spend out of what We have provided for them, {3} And who believe in what has been revealed to you, [O Muhammad], and what was revealed before you, and of the Hereafter they are certain [in faith]. {4} Those are upon [right] guidance from their Lord, and it is those who are the successful. {5}}. And He Glory be to Him said {O Children of Israel, remember My favor which I have bestowed upon you and fulfill My covenant upon you that I will fulfill your covenant from Me, and be afraid of [only] Me {40} And believe in what I have sent down confirming that which is [already] with you, and be not the first to disbelieve in it. And do not exchange My signs for a small price, and fear [only] Me. {41} And do not mix the truth with falsehood or conceal the truth while you know [it]. {42} And establish prayer and give zakah and bow with those who bow [in worship and obedience]. {43}}.
When He mentioned among the attributes of the pious belief in what was revealed to the Seal of Prophets and what was revealed before him to his brothers of prophets and messengers, it suited that to talk about some prophets and nations. So the Surah talked about Adam peace be upon him as it talked about the Children of Israel, and invited them to believe in what was revealed to the Messenger of Allah peace be upon him and what was revealed to the prophets who preceded him...

book_title: Al-Shawkani's Stance in his Tafsir regarding Munasabat
text:
He Almighty mentioned in the opening of the Surah the stance of the disbelievers and hypocrites towards the Holy Quran. In this is a preparation for the discussion of the Children of Israel and warning them against following the path of disbelief and hypocrisy.

**Correlation between the First Call in the Surah and the Call Directed to the Children of Israel:**
When the first call in this noble Surah came in a general form directed to all people inviting to the worship of Allah alone and reminding of His favors Almighty upon them, He Almighty said {O mankind, worship your Lord, who created you and those before you, that you may become righteous {21} [He] who made for you the earth a bed [spread out] and the sky a ceiling and sent down from the sky, rain and brought forth thereby fruits as provision for you. So do not attribute to Allah equals while you know [that there is nothing similar to Him]. {22} And if you are in doubt about what We have sent down upon Our Servant [Muhammad], then produce a surah the like thereof and call upon your witnesses other than Allah, if you should be truthful. {23} But if you do not - and you will never be able to - then fear the Fire, whose fuel is men and stones, prepared for the disbelievers. {24}}:
The first call came with a general invitation directed to all people to worship Allah Almighty, for He alone is deserving of worship, and worship is the path to piety. The Quran is the greatest sign with which Allah challenged all people, so there is no way to produce a Surah like it. There is no doubt in its being revealed from Allah nor doubt in what it contained of wisdom, rulings, stories, and parables.
The second call came directed to a specific group, the Children of Israel, reminding of His favors Almighty upon them and inviting them to believe in the Seal Prophet peace be upon him. So the first call came directed to all people and the second call came directed to a specific group, and this is mentioning the specific after the general...

book_title: Al-Shawkani's Stance in his Tafsir regarding Munasabat
text:
Ibn Juzayy al-Kalbi said in his Tafsir: "When He presented the invitation to people generally and mentioned their beginning: He invited the Children of Israel specifically, who are the Jews. The speech continued with them from here to the Hizb 'The foolish will say'. Sometimes He invites them with kindness and mentioning the favor upon them and their fathers, and sometimes with intimidation." (1)
Also, when the noble Surah talked about the Holy Quran in terms of its inimitability, it suited that to talk about some aspects of inimitability, including Quranic stories. So the story of Adam was mentioned, and after it the story of the Children of Israel.
Imam Al-Baydawi said: "Know that when He, Glory be to Him and Exalted, mentioned the proofs of Monotheism, Prophethood, and the Hereafter, and followed it by enumerating general blessings as affirmation and confirmation - for they, as precise occurrences, indicate a Wise Originator who has Creation and Command alone with no partner; and as reporting them according to what is established in previous books from one who did not learn them nor practice anything of them is informing of the unseen, miraculous, indicating the prophethood of the one informing about them; and as containing the creation of man and his origin and what is greater than that, indicate that He is capable of return (resurrection) just as He was capable of initiation - He addressed the people of knowledge and scripture among them and commanded them to remember Allah Almighty's favors upon them and fulfill His covenant in following the truth and pursuing arguments to be the first to believe in Muhammad, peace be upon him, and what was revealed to him. So He said {O Children of Israel}." (2)

**Correlation between the Story of Adam and the Story of the Children of Israel:**

text:
It was appropriate that the invitation of the Children of Israel, who are People of the Book and knowledge - before the invitation to believe in the Seal Prophet is directed to them, that this be preceded by - presenting a set of shining proofs and evidences paving the way to invite them, being People of the Book, to believe in this Seal Prophet. In the previous verses, it was established that the Holy Quran is a miraculous book with which Allah challenges all people, and that it is a book of guidance to the path of success and happiness in both abodes, and that it included the invitation to worship Allah alone, populate the universe, and work for the Hereafter, and that it contained the decisive word, profound wisdom, and clear truth in the stories of the predecessors. Among that is the verses' talk about the story of Adam peace be upon him, which is considered a shining proof that the Quran is from Allah; for how could Muhammad, if the Quran were from him, know this story which is only known through divine revelation? From here, these arguments, proofs, and facts which only appeared in the Holy Quran, among which was the talk about Adam peace be upon him, preceded the invitation of the Children of Israel to believe in the Seal Prophet.
When He Almighty mentioned His favors upon our father Adam peace be upon him, where He chose him, honored him, and dwelt him in Paradise with his wife Eve, but he was not safe from Satan's whispering and disobeyed Allah Almighty by eating from the forbidden tree, then repented and Allah accepted his repentance and he was expelled from Paradise for one sin: He mentioned Almighty His favors upon the Children of Israel; where He chose them, guided them, and saved them from Pharaoh and his soldiers, but they exchanged Allah's favor for disbelief and exchanged what is better for what is lower, and were insolent about the command of their Lord and persisted in rebellion and disobedience...

book_title: Al-Shawkani's Stance in his Tafsir regarding Munasabat
text:
Imam Al-Nisaburi said in his Tafsir: "When He Almighty established the proofs of Monotheism, Prophethood, and the Hereafter, then mentioned general favors to mankind, among which is the creation of Adam to the end of his story, He followed it with special favors upon the ancestors of the Jews to soften their obstinacy, win over their hearts, and alert to the prophethood of Muhammad peace be upon him; in terms of being news of the unseen included in the folds of that which guides them to the principles of religions and noble morals." (1).
If Adam peace be upon him was expelled from Paradise for one sin, what about them having surrendered their rein to Satan and followed desire yet they covet the Gardens? And he spoke truth who said:
*O looker gazing with the eyes of a sleeper... And witnessing the matter not as a witness.*
*Sins connect to sins and you hope... for the degrees of gardens by them and the success of the worshiper.*
*Did you forget that Allah expelled Adam from it... to the world for a single sin.*
Imam Al-Alusi said: "'O Children of Israel, remember My favor which I have bestowed upon you' is an address to a specific group of disbelievers contemporary to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, after the general address. He Glory be to Him placed it after the story of Adam because these people, after being given clear explanation and evident proof, and commanded, forbidden, and incited to follow the Unlettered Prophet whom they find written with them, the opposite appeared from them. So they exited the high paradise of faith and descended to the land of nature. Words were presented to them but they did not receive them with acceptance, so they missed what they missed. He turned to them calling to move them to listen to what comes of commands and prohibitions." (2)
From the foregoing, it becomes clear to us: That the discussion about the Children of Israel is one of the main axes and basic objectives of this noble Surah which was revealed after Hijra accompanying the building of the Islamic state, supporting it, fortifying it from the plots of enemies, laying the foundations of dealing with non-Muslims, and clarifying the optimal method in dialogue with them alongside inviting them.

text:
The discussion about the Children of Israel is appropriate to the introduction of the Surah; and its basic objectives which are building the Muslim society and fortifying it, and stating the foundations of relationship with the new society in Medina which includes various factions including the Jews. What preceded the discussion about the Children of Israel is but a preparation for it and a paving, where arguments and proofs preceded the invitation of the Children of Israel to believe in the Prophet Muhammad peace be upon him. Also, the correlation is clear between the general call mentioned in the Surah and the special call directed to the Children of Israel, as a way of mentioning the specific after the general to care for and draw attention to that specific. The correlation between the story of Adam peace be upon him and the story of the Children of Israel is multifaceted as previously mentioned. Both stories are full of lessons and sermons, rich in facts indicating that this Quran is from the Knower of the Unseen who knows what was and what will be, knows what is before us and what is behind us. The Children of Israel are the most in need of taking lesson from the story of our father Adam peace be upon him who left Paradise for one sin, tasted the bitterness of disobedience, saw its effect, and endured its consequences, despite Allah's prior choosing and honoring of him. Will the Jews take lesson? Or will they fall into Satan's traps and snares? In which party will they be and with which team will they stand? {We said, "Go down from it, all of you. And when guidance comes to you from Me, whoever follows My guidance - there will be no fear concerning them, nor will they grieve. {38} And those who disbelieve and deny Our signs - those will be companions of the Fire; they will abide therein eternally." {39}}
Here I should point out that the Surah from its beginning is a general address including all people including the Children of Israel, but the address directed to them and specific to them began from verse forty of the Surah.

book_title: Al-Shawkani's Stance in his Tafsir regarding Munasabat
text:
**The Fourth Requirement: His Inclusion of Many Munasabat (Correlations) in His Tafsir!**

Whoever contemplates Al-Shawkani's Tafsir finds that he has included numerous correlations in his Tafsir, contrary to his prior opinion on Munasabat. This opinion with which he prefaced his Tafsir is opposition and denial of those who undertook it and cared for it like Al-Biqa'i, Al-Haralli, Al-Razi (1) and others. Below we mention these faces contained in his Tafsir. We say, and success is from Allah:

**Explanatory Resumption (Al-Istin'af al-Bayani):**
Resumption: is bringing after complete speech a saying understood as an answer to an implied question (2).
An example of that is His saying Almighty in Surah Al-Baqarah {{Alif, Lam, Meem {1} This is the Book about which there is no doubt, a guidance for those conscious of Allah {2} Who believe in the unseen, establish prayer, and spend out of what We have provided for them, {3} And who believe in what has been revealed to you, [O Muhammad], and what was revealed before you, and of the Hereafter they are certain [in faith]. {4} Those are upon [right] guidance from their Lord, and it is those who are the successful. {5}}.
So His saying Almighty {Those are upon [right] guidance from their Lord, and it is those who are the successful. {5}}.
* As Al-Shawkani said in his Tafsir: [Speech resumed as explanatory resumption, as if it was said: What is the state of those combining piety, belief in the unseen, performing obligatory duties, and belief in what was revealed to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him and his family, and to those before him of prophets, peace be upon them? So it was said: Those are upon guidance. It can also be news about those who believe in the unseen etc., so it would be connected to what is before it.] (3)

**Confirming Resumption (Al-Istin'af al-Taqriri):**
An example of that is His saying Almighty in Surah Al-Ma'idah {You will surely find the most intense of the people in animosity toward the believers [to be] the Jews and those who associate others with Allah; and you will find the nearest of them in affection to the believers those who say, "We are Christians." That is because among them are priests and monks and because they are not arrogant. {82}}
Al-Shawkani said: [His saying {You will surely find} etc. is a resumed sentence confirming what is before it of enumerating the evils of the Jews and their faults] (1), which is by clarifying the intensity of their enmity to Muslims.
And in his interpretation of His saying Almighty from Surah Al-Nur {Allah is the Light of the heavens and the earth} [Verse 35 of Surah Al-Nur], the Sheikh clarifies the face of connection between this verse and the verses preceding it, saying: [When Glory be to Him clarified the rulings He clarified, He followed that with His being, Glory be to Him, in the utmost perfection. This sentence is resumed to confirm what is before it] (2). Meaning to confirm those previous rulings and clarify that they issued from the Possessor of Perfection and Majesty.

**Diversity in Speech and Moving from One Style to Another:**
It has been said: *The soul is not set right if it is diverted... except by moving from state to state.*
In the variety of styles is confirmation of arguments and proofs, establishment of creed and rulings, strengthening of souls and consoling them, and renewing their activity and turning to the Book of Allah Almighty.
* Al-Shawkani said explaining the secret of citing the story of Noah, peace be upon him, in Surah Hud:

[When Glory be to Him presented to the disbelievers contemporary to Muhammad, peace be upon him and his family, types of evidences which are clearer than the sun, He confirmed that by mentioning stories in the manner of diversity in speech and moving it from one style to another so that the sermon be more apparent, the argument clearer, and acceptance more complete. Indeed, I fear for you the punishment of a painful day. {26}} [Surah Hud]] 0 (1)

**Antithesis (Al-Tadadd):**
It is combining a meaning and its opposite. It is one of the rhetorical styles, like combining encouragement and intimidation, talking about disbelievers after talking about believers, and talking about Paradise after talking about Hell, and so on. It has been said:
*And by its opposite, things become clear*
*Two opposites when they gather are good... And the opposite shows its goodness by the opposite*
In Al-Shawkani's Tafsir, there are numerous examples where he highlighted this linking face between many verses. Below we mention examples from his Tafsir indicating that:
* In his interpretation of His saying Almighty from Surah Al-Baqarah ({Indeed, those who disbelieve - it is all the same for them whether you warn them or do not warn them - they will not believe. {6} Allah has set a seal upon their hearts and upon their hearing, and over their vision is a veil. And for them is a great punishment. {7}}), Al-Shawkani says: [Glory be to Him mentioned the party of evil after mentioning the party of good, cutting this speech from the first speech, titling it with what indicates that the nature of the disbeliever type is that warning is futile for them and that what is required of them of faith does not result from it, and that the existence of that (warning) is like its non-existence.] 0 (2)

**Appending Results to Premises:**
Among the faces of connection found in the Tafsir of Fath al-Qadir, for example, is what he mentioned in the interpretation of Allah's saying {Do they not look at what Allah has created - [how] their shadows incline to the right and to the left, prostrating to Allah, while they are humble? {48} And to Allah prostrates whatever is in the heavens and whatever is on the earth of living creatures, and the angels, and they are not arrogant. {49} They fear their Lord above them, and they do what they are commanded. {50} And Allah has said, "Do not take for yourselves two deities. He is but one God, so fear only Me." {51}} [Surah Al-Nahl].

He is but one God"}. So He Glory be to Him forbade taking two deities, then affirmed that divinity is exclusive to one God, who is Allah Glory be to Him.] (1)

**Mentioning the Specific after the General:**
Of that is what he mentioned in the interpretation of His saying Almighty from Surah Al-Nahl {And fulfill the covenant of Allah when you have taken it} He said: "Glory be to Him singled out from among the commands contained in His saying {Indeed, Allah orders justice and good conduct...} the fulfillment of covenant, so He said {And fulfill the covenant of Allah when you have taken it}." (2)

**Arrangement of the Surah's Subjects:**
Whoever reflects on the Quranic Surahs finds for each Surah its thematic unity through the interconnection of its sections, the proportionality of its verses, and the sequence of its subjects which, although numerous and diverse, revolve around one subject and aim at one purpose. Al-Shawkani pointed to this in his Tafsir, saying in the interpretation of Surah Al-Furqan explaining the secret of the arrangement of its subjects: "Glory be to Him spoke in this Surah on Monotheism because it is oldest and most important, then on Prophethood because it is the medium, then on the Hereafter because it is the conclusion." Thus the subjects of the Surah came arranged and sequential, all revolving around establishing the Islamic Creed with its three aspects: Divinities, Prophethoods, and Unseen Matters.

**Mentioning What Follows a Legal Ruling of Rulings Attached to it:**
An example of that is what Al-Shawkani mentioned in the interpretation of His saying Almighty {Mothers may breastfeed their children two complete years for whoever wishes to complete the nursing [period]. Upon the father is the mothers' provision and their clothing according to what is acceptable...} to the end of verse {233} of Surah Al-Baqarah}. He said: [When Allah Glory be to Him mentioned marriage and divorce, He mentioned breastfeeding because the spouses might separate while having a child between them. That is why it was said this is specific to divorced women, and it was said it is general.] (3)

**Drawing Parallels (Al-Tanzir):**
It is attaching the analogue to the analogue and clarifying the link between them:
* In Al-Shawkani's Tafsir, there are numerous examples of this. Among them is what he mentioned in highlighting the face of connection between the story of the two sons of Adam and what preceded it of the discussion about the Children of Israel. He Almighty said: {And recite to them the story of Adam's two sons, in truth, when they both offered a sacrifice [to Allah], and it was accepted from one of them but was not accepted from the other. Said [the latter], "I will surely kill you." Said [the former], "Indeed, Allah only accepts from the righteous [who fear Him]." {27}} etc. verses mentioned in Surah Al-Ma'idah.
Al-Shawkani says: [The face of connecting this to what is before it is alerting from Allah that the injustice of the Jews and their breaking of covenants and pacts is like the injustice of the son of Adam to his brother; for the disease is old and the evil is deep-rooted.] (1)
* Also among that is what he cited in clarifying the face of connection between His saying Almighty in Surah Al-Anfal {[It is] just as when your Lord brought you out of your home [for the battle of Badr] in truth, while indeed, a party among the believers were unwilling, {5} Arguing with you concerning the truth after it had become clear, as if they were being driven toward death while they were looking on. {6}} and what is before it:
