text: He says, may Allah have mercy on him: [His saying {Just as when your Lord brought you out of your home in truth}, meaning: The spoils are established for you just as your Lord brought you out of your home in truth, i.e., like the bringing out of your Lord. The meaning is: proceed with your command regarding spoils and give extra (Nafl) to whomever you wish even if they dislike it, because some of the Companions said to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him and his family, when he gave something to everyone who brought a prisoner: 'Most people remained without anything.' So the position of Kaf is accusative (Nasb) as we mentioned, and Al-Farra' said this. Abu Ubaida said it is an oath, meaning: 'By the One Who brought you out,' so the Kaf has the meaning of Waw and Ma has the meaning of Alladhi (The One Who). Al-Akhfash Sa'id bin Mas'ada said the meaning is: {Those are the believers, truly} just as your Lord brought you out. Ikrimah said the meaning is: 'Obey Allah and His Messenger just as your Lord brought you out.' It was said 'Just as He brought you out' is related to His saying 'For them are degrees,' meaning this promise to the believers is true in the Hereafter just as your Lord brought you out of your home with the truth obligated to Him, so He fulfilled your promise and gave you victory over your enemy and fulfilled for you. Al-Nahhas mentioned this and chose it. It was said the Kaf in Kama is the Kaf of similitude by way of recompense, like the saying of a speaker to his slave: 'Just as I sent you to my enemies and they deemed you weak and you asked for help so I helped you and strengthened you and removed your ailment, so take them now and punish them.' It was said the Kaf is in the position of nominative (Raf') as the predicate of an omitted subject, the estimation being: 'This state is like the state of your bringing out,' meaning that their state in disliking what you saw regarding giving extra to the warriors is like their state in disliking your exit for war. The author of Al-Kashshaf mentioned this. 'In truth' is related to an omitted word, the estimation being: 'An exit clothed in truth in which there is no doubt.' The sentence 'while indeed, a party among the believers were unwilling' is in the position of accusative as circumstantial (Hal), meaning: Just as He brought you out in the state of their dislike for that. Because when Allah promised them one of the two parties, either the caravan or the band (army), they desired the caravan for what was in it of spoil and safety from fighting, as will be explained. The sentence 'Arguing with you concerning the truth after it had become clear' is either in the position of accusative as a second Hal or resumed as an answer to an implied question. Their arguing was when he called them to one of the two parties, and the caravan was missed, and he ordered them to fight the band, and they did not have much preparation for that. It was hard on them and they said: 'If you had informed us of fighting, we would have prepared and completed the equipment.'] (1)

Of that is the preface and paving for stories that are mentioned. And the preface and paving for legal rulings that are mentioned. Al-Shawkani says in his interpretation of Surah Al-Ahzab: [Then Glory be to Him mentioned a parable as paving and preparation for what follows of Quranic rulings which are from the revelation He commanded to be followed, saying {Allah has not made for a man two hearts in his interior}. There is difference regarding the cause of revelation of this verse as will come. It was said it is a parable Allah struck for the one who pronounces Zihar (comparing wife to mother's back), meaning just as a man cannot have two hearts, likewise the wife of the one pronouncing Zihar is not his mother so that there would be two mothers for him, and likewise the adopted son is not a son of two men. It was said one of the hypocrites used to say: I have a heart ordering me such and a heart such. So the verse was revealed to refute hypocrisy and clarify that it does not combine with Islam just as two hearts do not combine...] (4)

Al-Shawkani answers this in his Tafsir, saying: [{They ask you about the new moons. Say, "They are measurements of time for the people and for Hajj"} In it is clarification of the face of wisdom in the increase and decrease of the crescent moon, and that is for the sake of clarifying the timings by which people time their worships and transactions, such as fasting, breaking fast, Hajj, gestation period, waiting period ('Iddah), leases, oaths, and other things... Glory be to Him singled out Hajj for mention because it is something where knowing the time is needed, and postponing (Nasi') regarding its time is not permissible, and due to the great hardship on one to whom the time of his rituals becomes confused or who misses its time or the time of some of it. Some scholars of rhetoric made this answer, i.e., His saying {Say, "They are measurements of time"}, of the wise style (Uslub al-Hakim), which is meeting the addressee with other than what he expects, alerting that it is more worthy of intent. The face of that is that they asked about the bodies of crescent moons regarding their increase and decrease, so they were answered with the wisdom for which that increase and decrease existed, because that is more worthy to be intended by the questioner and more deserving to look for its knowledge. His saying {And it is not righteousness to enter houses from the back}. The face of connection of this to the question about new moons: The Ansar, when they performed Hajj, would not enter from the doors of their houses if one of them returned to his house after his Ihram before completing his Hajj, because they believed that the Muhrim (pilgrim in Ihram) should not have a barrier between him and the sky. They used to scale the backs of their houses. Abu Ubaida said: This is a proverb. The meaning is: Righteousness is not that you ask the ignorant, but righteousness is piety, so ask the scholars, just as you say: I approached this matter from its door. It was said: It is a metaphor for sexual intercourse with women, and that they were commanded to approach them from the front, not the rear. And other things were said.] (1)

Of that is what Al-Shawkani mentioned in the interpretation of His saying Almighty {And your god is one God. There is no deity [worthy of worship] except Him, the Entirely Merciful, the Especially Merciful. {163} Indeed, in the creation of the heavens and earth, and the alternation of the night and the day, and the [great] ships which sail through the sea with that which benefits people, and what Allah has sent down from the heavens of rain, giving life thereby to the earth after its lifelessness and dispersing therein every [kind of] moving creature, and [His] directing of the winds and the clouds controlled between the heaven and the earth are signs for a people who use reason. {164}} [Surah Al-Baqarah]. Al-Shawkani said: [When Glory be to Him mentioned Monotheism by His saying {And your god is one God}, He followed that with the evidence indicating it, which is these matters that are of the greatest craftsmanship of the Wise Maker, with the knowledge of every sane person that it is not possible for any of the gods affirmed by the disbelievers to come with any of them or be capable of it or part of it.] (1)

**Correlation between the Surah and its Predecessor:**
Al-Shawkani did not care much for this aspect, but in the interpretation of Surah Al-Hajj, he cited a correlation between it and what is before it, saying: "When the speech in the conclusion of the previous Surah dragged on to the mention of Resurrection and what is before it and after it, Glory be to Him started in this Surah by mentioning the Resurrection and its horrors, urging piety which is the most beneficial provision, so He Almighty said: (O mankind, fear your Lord. Indeed, the convulsion of the [final] Hour is a terrible thing). (2)
In the interpretation of Surah Quraysh, he mentioned its connection to its predecessor, i.e., Surah Al-Fil which precedes it in the arrangement of the Mushaf. Surah Al-Fil was revealed after Surah Al-Kafirun, and Surah Quraysh was revealed after Surah Al-Tin.

text:
Al-Shawkani, may Allah have mercy on him, says: [The Lam in His saying {Li-ilafi} (For the accustomed security): It was said it relates to the end of the Surah before it, as if He Glory be to Him said: I destroyed the companions of the elephant for the coalition of Quraysh. Al-Farra' said: This Surah is connected to the first Surah because Glory be to Him reminded the people of Mecca of His great favor upon them in what He did to the Abyssinians, then He said {For the accustomed security of Quraysh}, meaning We did that to the companions of the elephant as a favor from Us to Quraysh. That is because Quraysh used to go out for their trade and were not raided in Jahiliyyah; people would say they are the people of the House of Allah Almighty. Until the owner of the elephant came to demolish the Kaaba and take its stones to build a house in Yemen for people to make pilgrimage to. So Allah Almighty destroyed them and reminded them of His favor, meaning He did that for the accustomed security of Quraysh, i.e., so they remain accustomed to going out and are not dared against. Ibn Qutayba mentioned something similar. Al-Zajjaj said: The meaning is 'So He made them like eaten straw for the accustomed security of Quraysh', meaning Allah destroyed the companions of the elephant so that Quraysh and what they were accustomed to of the winter and summer journey would remain. In Al-Kashshaf, it is said: The Lam is related to His saying 'So let them worship'; He commanded them to worship Him for the sake of their habit of the two journeys. The Fa' entered because of the meaning of condition in the speech. Al-Khalil bin Ahmad preceded the author of Al-Kashshaf to this saying. The meaning is: If they do not worship Him for His other favors, let them worship Him for this majestic favor. Al-Kisa'i and Al-Akhfash said: The Lam is Lam of wonder, meaning: Wonder at the accustomed security of Quraysh. And it was said it means 'Ila' (to).] (1).

**Appropriateness of Citing the Story:**
Among the correlations the Sheikh highlighted sometimes is clarifying the occasion for which the story was driven. Of that is what he mentioned regarding the appropriateness of citing the story of the two sons of Adam, peace be upon him, in Surah Al-Ma'idah in the context of talking about the corruptions and injustice of the Children of Israel: [The face of connecting this to what is before it is alerting from Allah that the injustice of the Jews and their breaking of covenants and pacts is like the injustice of the son of Adam to his brother; for the disease is old and the evil is deep-rooted.] (2)

Of that also is what he mentioned regarding the secret of citing the story of the wife of Lot and the wife of Noah in Surah Al-Tahrim, where he says, may Allah have mercy on him: [Yahya bin Salam said: Allah struck a parable for those who disbelieved to warn Aisha and Hafsa against opposing the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him and his family, when they backed each other against him. How excellent is he who said: Mentioning the two wives of the two Prophets after mentioning their story and their backing against the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him and his family, guides most completely and hints most eloquently that the intended meaning is frightening them along with the rest of the Mothers of the Believers, and clarifying that even if they are under the protection of the best of Allah's creation and the Seal of His Messengers, that does not avail them against Allah at all. Allah protected them from the sin of that backing by the sincere correct repentance that occurred from them.] (1)
* In his interpretation of Surah Hud, where numerous stories of Prophets were mentioned starting with the story of Noah peace be upon him, Al-Shawkani says: [When Glory be to Him presented to the disbelievers contemporary to Muhammad, peace be upon him and his family, types of evidences which are clearer than the sun, He confirmed that by mentioning stories in the manner of diversity in speech and moving it from one style to another so that the sermon be more apparent, the argument clearer, and acceptance more complete. He said {{And We had certainly sent Noah to his people, [saying], "Indeed, I am to you a clear warner {25} That you not worship except Allah. Indeed, I fear for you the punishment of a painful day. {26}} (2)

**Linking Story to Story:**
Among the faces of correlations highlighted by the Sheikh is linking between story and story. In his interpretation of Surah Saba', he mentions the correlation between the stories of David and Solomon, peace be upon them, and the story of Saba', saying: [When Glory be to Him mentioned the state of some of those grateful for His favors, He followed it with the state of some of those denying them, so He said {There was for [the tribe of] Saba'} (3) ] (4)

**Conclusion**
**Summary of Research and Results**

The book "Fath al-Qadir al-Jami' bayna Fannay al-Riwayah wa al-Dirayah min 'Ilm al-Tafsir" by Imam Al-Shawkani is one of the masterpieces of Tafsir books and its comprehensive foundations. It included Tafsir by narration as well as Tafsir by knowledge (Tafsir by tradition and Tafsir by opinion).
Al-Shawkani went in his Tafsir to the view that researching the science of Munasabat is a form of affectation, that there is no benefit from it, and that it is speaking by pure forbidden opinion, and he criticized Al-Biqa'i and others for their attention to this science.

book_title: Al-Shawkani's Stance in his Tafsir regarding Munasabat
text:
I have responded to him in this research while discussing the most important issues he raised. I clarified the benefits and fruits of studying the science of Munasabat, this beneficial science through which a face of the faces of the Holy Quran's inimitability becomes clear to us: that is in terms of the correlation of its verses and coordination of its Surahs. The Holy Quran is a single thematic unity, and its verses and Surahs are a single structure like pearls increasing in beauty when strung and not decreasing in value when unstrung. This is in addition to clarifying meanings and their richness, and the clarity of purposes before exegetes who cannot do without it.
The Glorious Quran was distinguished by this unique order, this arranged casting, this wondrous variation, this richness in styles, and moving from subject to subject, from wisdom to wisdom, from story to story, and from parable to parable, without that leading to disturbance or defect, lethargy or boredom, contradiction or difference. Rather, consistency and harmony, observing the nature of souls, easing for readers, and providing insight and reminder for those of intellect. This is alongside its piecemeal revelation - according to incidents and occurrences - contrary to what is customary in previous books which were revealed all at once. Thus it combined numerous characteristics not present in previous books: its revelation wholly according to wisdom, its revelation separately according to events and what legislation requires of gradation in rulings, in addition to this wondrous arrangement. A table filled and teeming, gardens lush and fresh, flowering and fruitful, pleasing the looking eyes. Its branches intertwined, its flowers embraced, its birds harmonized, its fruits ripened, its streams mixed, its pearls ordered, and its jewels consistent in a unique necklace and arranged wire.
The one looking into Al-Shawkani's Tafsir witnesses in it numerous and diverse examples of correlations between verses, where he highlighted many faces of connection between verses, including:
* Explanatory Resumption
* Confirming Resumption
* Diversity in speech and moving it from one style to another
* Antithesis: combining a meaning and its opposite, like combining encouragement and intimidation
* Appending Results to Premises..

We support Al-Shawkani in that affectation is forbidden in Tafsir or otherwise, and that it is not permissible to speak by pure forbidden opinion. The science of Munasabat requires reflection and contemplation, not affectation and arbitrariness. It requires a comprehensive holistic view of the verses, reflecting on their meanings and purposes, their connection to the general purpose of the Surah, and their connection to their predecessor and successor, with stating the type of link binding the verses. This science is indispensable for any exegete, because it aids in understanding the meaning, preferring between opinions, knowing the general purposes of verses and Surahs, and other benefits.

The Holy Quran was revealed piecemeal according to incidents and occurrences, observing gradualism in legislation, keeping pace with the stages the Islamic Da'wah passed through in its Meccan and Madinan eras and what each stage required. It was collected in breasts and lines according to what is in the Preserved Tablet, where Gabriel peace be upon him used to teach the Messenger of Allah peace be upon him the place of every verse in its Surah, in addition to the arrangement of Surahs as will be explained. The Companions may Allah be pleased with them memorized it according to this arrangement, and that was observed in the Uthmani Mushafs. If its revelation piecemeal had wisdoms and benefits that are not hidden, then its collection in this Divinely Appointed arrangement has wisdoms and benefits. And if its revelation piecemeal is a characteristic of its characteristics unique from previous books, then this arrangement is a characteristic of its characteristics. If its revelation piecemeal is miracles and miracles, then its collection in this splendor and beauty is the miracle of miracles. Is it reasonable that its arrangement in the Mushaf be different from the order of its revelation and then there is no wisdom for that? Why do we strive in seeking wisdoms and purposes of divine legislations and then demand ignoring the wisdom of the divine arrangement of His Mighty Book! 0
The wonder of wonders is how Al-Shawkani criticized Al-Biqa'i for his interest in this science in his Tafsir "Nazm al-Durar", then we see him praising this Tafsir and the path of its author in it as stated in his book "Al-Badr al-Tali'" during his biography of him: "Whoever examines deeply his book translated for him in Tafsir which he made about the correlations between verses and Surahs knows that he is among the vessels of knowledge, excessive in intelligence, combining the science of reason and tradition. Often something in the Book confuses me, so I return to the extensive and concise Tafsirs and find nothing that cures, and I return to this book - Nazm al-Durar - and find in it what is beneficial mostly." So the wonder is how he criticizes his care for this noble science, then you see him praising him and his path in his Tafsir which combined tradition and opinion! Doesn't this remind us of Al-Buhturi's saying...
